history.narrative: Law 8-124 was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 8-374, which was referred to the Committee on Human Services. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on February 13, 1990, and February 27, 1990, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on March 15, 1990, it was assigned Act No. 8-177 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review.

LAW 8-124 "Medicaid Coverage Expansion Act of 1990 Pursuant to Section 412 of the District of Columbia Self- Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, P. L. 93-198 the Act the Council of the District of Columbia adopted Bill No. 8-374 on first and second readings, February 13, 1990, and February 27, 1990, respectively. Following the signature of the Mayor on March 15, 1990, this legislation was assigned Act No. 8-177, published in the March 30, 1990, edition of the D.C. Register Vol. 37 page 2087) and transmitted to Congress on March 22, 1990 for a 30-day review, in accordance with Section 602(c)(1) of the Act. The Council of the District of Columbia hereby gives notice that the 30-day Congressional Review Period has expired, and therefore, cites this enactment as D.C. Codification, District of Columbia Code (1991 Supplement) IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA To expand Medicaid coverage for pregnant women, infants, and children. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Medicaid Coverage Expansion Act of 1990 Sec. 2. Section 1 of An Act To enable the District of Columbia to receive Federal assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act for a medical assistance program, and for other purposes Medical Assistance Act approved December 27, 1967 (81Stat. 7~4; D.C. Code, sec. 1-359 is amended by adding a new subsection (c) to read as follows c)(1) A pregnant woman or an infant under 1 year of age with an income up to 185% of th@ federal poverty line, as authorized by section 1902(a)(I) of the Social Security Amendments Act of 1965~ approved July 30, 1965 (79 Stat. 343; 42 U.S.C. 1396a(1)(a 2) A child born after September 30, 1983, who has not attained the age of 8 years and whose family income is not more than I00% of the federal poverty line, as authorized by section 1902 of the Social Security Amendments Act of 1965, approved July 30, 1965 (79 Stat. 343; 42 U.S.C. 1396a 3) A pregnant woman or a child during a presumptive eligibility period as aUthorized by section 1902(a) of the Social Security Amendments Act of 1965, approved July 30, 1965 (79 star. 343; 42 U.S.C. 1396a(a Sec. 3. The p~:ovisions of section 1(¢ 3) of the Medical Assistance Program Act shall apply after October i, 1991.
